ranked_diseases.explanation: All three reference cases with identical presentation (Stage 5 CKD) were diagnosed with this condition. ADTKD-UMOD is caused by UMOD mutations and typically presents with progressive CKD in adulthood.
ADTKD-MUC1 is another form of autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease that presents similarly to ADTKD-UMOD with progressive CKD in adults.
ADTKD-REN is a rarer form of ADTKD that can present with CKD, though often has earlier onset and may include hyperuricemia and anemia.
ADTKD-SEC61A1 is another form of ADTKD that presents with progressive CKD, though less common than UMOD and MUC1 variants.
ADTKD-DNAJB11 is a recently identified form of ADTKD that can present with CKD in adulthood, similar to other ADTKD subtypes.
ADPKD typically presents with bilateral kidney cysts and can progress to ESRD by age 50, though cysts are not mentioned in this case.
PKD2 has a milder phenotype than PKD1 but can still lead to ESRD in middle age. Absence of cyst description makes this less likely.
While typically presenting in childhood, some cases of NPHP1 can have later onset and present with tubulointerstitial nephritis leading to ESRD.
Autosomal dominant Alport syndrome can present with progressive CKD, though typically includes hematuria and hearing loss which are not mentioned.
IgA nephropathy is a common cause of CKD that can progress to ESRD, though typically presents with hematuria and proteinuria earlier in disease course.
